bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, July 6, 1922

div1.p: Carter gives his opinion as to whether Hanson should pursue a position with the Peruvian Health Department. He doubts that an African campaign will ever take place.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, July 6, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
July 6, 1922.
Dr. Henry Hanson, Director General,
Campana Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Peru,
Oficina Central, Avenida Pierola 545,
Lima, Peru, S. A.
Dear Doctor Hanson:
div1.p: Your letter of June 15th. to hand.

I have received no MSS from Dr. Ezayguirre, though you have men-
tioned it as sent both in this letter and your previous one. Best hold
on to the copy you have and bring it with you, so as to avoid the chance
of losing it in the mails.

1/ You are perfectly welcome to publish the collection of my ar-
ticles you have in Spanish and--if you think it worth while--I could
have a copy made of the first article on House Infection and send it you.
It is at the Surgeon General's Library as a “permanent loan.”

If Leguia is strong enough--I know he is willing unless it imperils
his position--to give you the required backing against politicians in
the Sanitary Department, you could probably do good work there--useful
to Peru--with even the amount of money that they must spend, for I sup-
pose they are still continuing the “medicos titulares” and “medicos de-
partmental.”

For the position to be managed honestly, with a well devised plan
for developement in the future and with as much energy as the means at
hand allows, would be a good thing, if it can be kept up, but two dif-
ficulties come in:--

a/ Whether Leguia's position is staple enough for him not to
have to use the Sanitary Department as a pawn in his political compaign:
and b How long it would be necessary to continue American supervision.

I doubt if the first can be answered in the affirmative and I
am inclined to think the second would be for a considerable number of
years.

I disagree with you in thinking that an American Advisor would
be of a great deal of value as it is extremely easy for a Director, act-
ing selfishly and in bad faith--as Cardenas at least would have done--
to block all the effects of advice, however good or however completely
accepted on paper. There are honest men in Peru, however, and--though
probably no so many--some of force. Frankly, I think Saintz and--to
a lesser degree--Caballero were such and probably Mediota, the engineer.
Whether you could find such a one and use him as an understudy--say for
two to five years--and have him continue your work, I do not know.

What I would like to do in your place would be to hold the matter
open: report to Dr. Rose on leave without pay--it would, of course, not
be fair to receive pay for attending to my own business: see what open-
ings there are for good sanitary work from the I. H. B. and the possi-
bility of getting assistance from them for either sanitary field or
laboratory work in Peru. They would be more apt to grant some of this
if the man in charge were one they trusted. Also, you could see about
putting Carl to school in the U. S. His education is a problem you have
also to meet. You say “If I were a young man without a family I should
enjoy the adventure for awhile.” Unquestionably, Martha: Virgil and
Mrs. Hanson are a family, but if Carl be provided for you are left in
the position of a young man.

Now this is not advice. It is just how a man from another stand-
point sees your problem and it may give you a side-light on it.

From a monetary standpoint--not by any means the whole, or even
the main consideration, and yet to be considered: I do not know what
your outlook in the U. S. would be right now. Nothing would be permanent
permanent
3.
with the I. H. B. and the home difficulties would be, I suspect, as
great as in Peru: Heiser is in the Phillipines for a years stay: and
Darling, you know, went from Malacca to Fiji to San Paulo.

State and municipal health positions are 1,000% better than they
were 20 years ago and are especially good in the North-west. What your
chances would be with them I do not know. If taken up as a life work,
naturally, the sooner you get into them the better, even if you went into
them at a low salary.

I am quite certain that no Director has as yet been chosen for
the African investigation of yellow fever, but I am not quite certain
whether that investigation will ever be made. If the business is put
off much longer and no yellow fever is reported from Africa it might well
be considered unnecessary.

Please let me know when you will arrive in New York as it will be
a great pleasure to me to meet you and talk over matters. You would pro-
bably send a wireless to the I. H. B. any way and you could ask them to
wire me.

My address will be
Dr. H. R. Carter,
New Glasgow P. O.
Amherst County,
Virginia.
“Geddes.”
This address I will also have in their hands.

Looking forward to seeing you and with very best remembrances to
you all, in which Laura joins.
